result.markdown:
--- title: Generate Reproducible & Live HTML and PDF Conference Posters Using RMarkdown author: - name: Anton S. Hesse affil: 1 orcid: '0000-0001-8456-7343' - name: Christopher J. Lundstrom orcid: '0000-0002-1527-1685' affil: 1 affiliation: - num: 1 address: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities, School of Kinesiology column_numbers: 3 logoright_name: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/brentthorne/posterdown/master/images/betterhexlogo.png logoleft_name: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/brentthorne/posterdown/master/images/betterhexlogo.png output: posterdown::posterdown_html: self_contained: false bibliography: packages.bib editor_options: markdown: wrap: 72 --- ::: {.cell .hidden} ```{.r .cell-code .hidden} knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE) ``` ::: # Abstract ## Purpose Cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) is the gold standard for non-invasively measuring cardiorespiratory fitness and is popular in many fields. CPET analyzes expired gases, usually generating one data point per breath (breath-by-breath). Consequentially, this data requires processing before later analysis because respiratory variability is much higher than the underlying metabolism it reflects. There is no universal method to process breath-by-breath data, and previous research shows that different approaches can affect downstream results. Moreover, there is little research on the popularity of different data processing methods and how often they are described in peer-reviewed literature. This scoping review aims to document the popularity and prevalence of CPET data processing methods. ## Methods We followed current scoping review methodology and searched three databases for papers whose methods included CPET with gas exchange. We screened those results using regular expressions and machine learning to identify papers where authors collected gas data breath-by-breath. Using regular expressions, we documented which, if any, gas data processing procedures were described in the methods section regarding outlier removal, interpolation, and averaging methods. ## Results Of the 8420 articles analyzed, 377 (4.5%) and 583 (6.9%) described outlier removal and interpolation, respectively. An estimated 66.8 ± 2.8% reported averaging methods (n = 1078). When documented, the most popular outlier cutoffs are mean ± 3 or 4 SD (39.0% and 51.7%, respectively), and the dominating interpolation time frame and procedure were one second (94.0%) and linear interpolation (92.2%), respectively. When described, the most popular averaging methods are 30 (30.8%), 60 (12.4%), 15 (11.6%), 10 (11.0%), and 20 (8.1%) second bin averages. ## Conclusions Despite the known impact on later analyses, only two-thirds of studies using breath-by-breath data clearly documented their averaging methods. Few papers explicitly describe gas data processing regarding outlier removal and interpolation. The importance of data processing depends on the subsequent analysis, but better documentation can improve reproducibility and study comparisons. # Introduction - Some combination of outlier removal, interpolation, and data averaging is typically required before calculating VO2max, ventilatory thresholds, and VO2 kinetics from CPETs - Prior research has shown data averaging duration affects calculated VO2max [@robergs2003; @robergs2010], but less is known about how outlier removal and interpolation affect this and other values - Before investigating how data processing decisions affect later outcomes, it is important to determine the prevalence of these procedures when reported - Quantifying the reporting percentage of data processing decisions improves study reproducibility # Methods - This scoping review followed the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses extension for Scoping Reviews - We downloaded a list of original, peer-reviewed articles from 3 databases that likely included original research on human subjects with breath-by-breath data collection and an exercise test - Downloaded full-text articles were converted articles to .txt format and the text was normalized easier analysis - We used regular expressions and machine learning classification algorithms to remove articles not satisfying the required criteria - We extracted text regarding outlier, interpolation, and data averaging methods using regular expressions and quantified their reporting frequency and prevalence when reported This package uses the same workflow approach as the R Markdown you know and love. Basically it goes from RMarkdown \> Knitr \> Markdown \> Pandoc \> HTML/CSS \> PDF. You can even use the bibliography the same way [@R-posterdown]. # Results Usually you want to have a nice table displaying some important results that you have calculated. In `posterdown` this is as easy as using the `kable` table formatting you are probably use to as per typical R Markdown formatting. You can reference tables like so: Table \@ref(tab:mytable). Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam placerat augue at velit tincidunt semper. Donec elementum porta posuere. Nullam interdum, odio at tincidunt feugiat, turpis nisi blandit eros, eu posuere risus felis non quam. Nam eget lorem odio. Duis et aliquet orci. Phasellus nec viverra est. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code .hidden} knitr::kable(iris[1:10, 1:4], caption = 'Table caption.',align = 'c',"html") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Table caption.
Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width
5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2
4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2
4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2
4.6 3.1 1.5 0.2
5.0 3.6 1.4 0.2
5.4 3.9 1.7 0.4
4.6 3.4 1.4 0.3
5.0 3.4 1.5 0.2
4.4 2.9 1.4 0.2
4.9 3.1 1.5 0.1
````` ::: ::: Or with figures: Figure \@ref(fig:standard-plot), or Figure \@ref(fig:morefigs). ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code .hidden} plot(mtcars[1:2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Great figure!](ACSM-Poster_files/figure-html/standard-plot-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data <- iris plot(x = data$Sepal.Length, y = data$Sepal.Width, col = data$Species, pch = 19, xlab = "Sepal Length (cm)", ylab = "Sepal Width (cm)") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Amazing, right?!](ACSM-Poster_files/figure-html/morefigs-1.png){width=80%} ::: ::: # Next Steps Aliquam sed faucibus risus, quis efficitur erat. Vestibulum semper mauris quis tempus eleifend. Aliquam sagittis dictum ipsum, quis viverra ligula eleifend ut. Curabitur sagittis vitae arcu eget faucibus. In non elementum felis. Duis et aliquam nunc. Nunc pulvinar sapien nunc, vel pretium nisi efficitur in. Fusce fringilla maximus leo et maximus. Fusce at ligula laoreet, iaculis mi at, auctor odio. Praesent sed elementum justo. Aenean consectetur risus rhoncus tincidunt efficitur. Praesent dictum mauris at diam maximus maximus [@R-posterdown]. # Conclusion Try `posterdown` out! Hopefully you like it! ::: {.cell .hidden} ```{.r .cell-code .hidden} knitr::write_bib(c('knitr','rmarkdown','posterdown','pagedown'), 'packages.bib') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr .hidden} ``` Warning in knitr::write_bib(c("knitr", "rmarkdown", "posterdown", "pagedown"), : package(s) posterdown, pagedown not found ``` ::: ::: # References
